topic.title: HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform: Installation Prerequisites

section.title: General Prerequisites
section.note: You must satisfy all prerequisites before beginning installation.

ul.li:
Ensure that the HPE Helion OpenStack environment you are using meets the following requirements:
The HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform requires HPE Helion OpenStack version 2.0 with a KVM hypervisor.
The Cinder block storage backend must be configured to use VSA, 3Par, or Ceph.
The Swift Object Storage service must be configured. Swift is required for Database Service backup and replication functionality, and is a requirement for production deployments. Swift is also used by the installer, and is needed.
If you did not create the Service Network , you must do so before proceeding.
The HP Helion Development Platform accesses the public URL for the Identity service endpoint. The SSL certificate installed with your HPE Helion OpenStack environment must be configured for your specific domain/IP before proceeding.

li.p: The system running the installer needs to have Python 2.7. Most modern operating systems include this as part of their base toolkit. This document is geared toward a Linux operating system, but this does not preclude the installer from running on other operating systems with appropriate modifications to the command-line statements.
For Windows and .NET support, due to licensing requirements, you must create and deploy your own Windows and SQL Server images. This requires the following:

ul.li: Windows images must be created in a MacOS or Linux environment.
You must have a Windows Server 2012 Enterprise (non-evaluation) image.
A volume license for Windows Server 2012 Enterprise is strongly recommended.
Additional tools (VirtIO and Virtual Box) are also required. See Building and Deploying Windows DEA and SQL Server Express Images for more information.

section.title: Gather Information
section.p: You will need the following information:

dlentry.dd: IP address of the HPE Helion OpenStack lifecycle manager (previously known as the deployer node). Contact your Administrator if needed.

The OpenStack username of a cloud admin that has rights to perform a service update for the selected service. This value is located in the ~/service.osrc file on the lifecycle manager. Contact your Administrator if needed.

The OpenStack password of a cloud admin that has rights to perform a service update for the selected service. This value is located in the ~/service.osrc file on the lifecycle manager. Contact your Administrator if needed.

section.title: Set Proxy Shell Variables
section.note: All of the following procedures are performed on the HPE Helion OpenStack lifecycle manager. SSH to the lifecycle manager before attempting any of these procedures.
section.p: If your network uses a proxy, it may be necessary to set the https_proxy and http_proxy shell variables.

ol.li:
If your network uses a proxy, you must define the proxy exclusion list (no_proxy)
Source the keystone RC file.source keystone.osrc
Get the Keystone public endpoint IP addressKEYSTONE_IP_PUBLIC=$(openstack endpoint list | grep keystone | grep public | grep -Eo '[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}')echo 'KEYSTONE PUBLIC IP: ' $KEYSTONE_IP_PUBLIC or fully-qualified domain name, depending on your HPE Helion OpenStack deployment.id=$(openstack endpoint list | grep identity | cut -d "|" -f2 | tr -d " ")openstack endpoint show $id | grep publicurl | cut -d "|" -f3 | cut -d "/" -f3 | cut -d ":" -f1
Get the Keystone internal endpoint IP addressKEYSTONE_IP_INTERNAL=$(openstack endpoint list | grep keystone | grep internal | grep -Eo '[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}')echo 'KEYSTONE INTERNAL IP: ' $KEYSTONE_IP_INTERNAL or fully-qualified domain name, depending on your HPE Helion OpenStack deployment.id=$(openstack endpoint list | grep identity | cut -d "|" -f2 | tr -d " ")openstack endpoint show $id | grep internalurl | cut -d "|" -f3 | cut -d "/" -f3 | cut -d ":" -f1
Set the IP address values for no_proxy. Ensure that each and every Keystone AUTH_URL IP is included in the no-proxy list.export no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.1,$KEYSTONE_IP_PUBLIC,$KEYSTONE_IP_INTERNAL

If your HPE Helion OpenStack deployment is behind a firewall, verify that the Sherpa proxy shell variables have been set. If these variables have not been set, either set them or follow the download instructions to acquire the packages without using the Sherpa service.

section.title: Verify Connectivity to Public Endpoints
section.note: All of the following procedures are performed on the HPE Helion OpenStack lifecycle manager. SSH to the lifecycle manager before attempting any of these procedures.

ol.li: Source the Keystone RC file. source keystone.osrc

Verify access to the Keystone public endpoint: KEYSTONE_URL_PUBLIC=`openstack endpoint list | grep keystone | grep public | grep -Eo '(http|https)://{1}\S+'`wget -t3 --timeout=5 -O/dev/null --no-check-certificate -q $KEYSTONE_URL_PUBLIC && echo exists OK || echo ERROR cannot reach $KEYSTONE_URL_PUBLIC

Verify access to the Sherpa public endpoint. If there is no access, see the Sherpa troubleshooting information, particularly how to set the http_proxy shell variables.SHERPA_URL_PUBLIC=`openstack endpoint list | grep sherpa | grep public | grep -Eo '(http|https)://{1}\S+' | sed -e 's/v1$//'`wget -t3 --timeout=5 -O/dev/null --no-check-certificate -q $SHERPA_URL_PUBLIC && echo exists OK || echo ERROR cannot reach $SHERPA_URL_PUBLIC
